questions.text: At physiological pH, buffering action in blood is caused by_______.
questions.solution:
At physiological pH, buffering action in blood is caused by histidine. 

The imidazole group of histidine has a pKa value of 6.5-7.4, which is close to physiological pH. Hence, histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

questions.text: Phenylalanine is the precursor of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Phenylalanine is not a precursor of melatonin.

Serotonin is the precursor of melatonin and is derived from tryptophan.

The derivatives of phenylalanine are:

  • Tyrosine → Thyroxine
  • Dopa → Melanin
  • Dopamine
  • Nor-epinephrine
  • Epinephrine

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease type I  is due to a defect in _____.
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) type I is due to impaired alpha-Ketoacid decarboxylase component of BCKAD (branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase) complex, leading to defective decarboxylation reaction and the formation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and their toxic byproducts (keto-acids) in blood and urine.

A peculiar odor (burnt sugar) is found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Note: Amino-acids and disorders of their metabolism are invariably being asked in NEET as well as in AIIMS examinations.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: Glycosylation is known for its role in the following processes except for ________.

choices.text: Anchoring trans-membrane proteins by increasing hydrophobicity

questions.solution:
Glycosylation does not anchor trans-membrane proteins by increasing hydrophobicity.

Sugar chains:

  • increase the hydrophilicity of glycosylated proteins.
  • Change physicochemical properties of the protein such as solubility, viscosity, charge, conformation, and denaturation
  • Provide binding sites for various molecules
  • Provide cell surface recognition signals
  • Ensure correct folding of proteins and target incorrectly folded proteins for transport from the endoplasmic reticulum back to the cytosol for catabolism
  • Protect peptide hormones and other plasma proteins against clearance by the liver
  • Permit anchoring of extracellular proteins in the cell membrane, and of intracellular proteins inside subcellular organelles
  • Direct intracellular migration, sorting and secretion of proteins

questions.text: An infant was admitted with failure to thrive. His reports show hypoglycemia, high glutamine, and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose.  Parenteral dextrose was given after which the child recovered in 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
This infant with failure to thrive, hypoglycemia, elevated levels of glutamine and uracil levels most likely has hyperammonemia type 2. This condition occurs due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine. Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated. Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Reducing intake of ammonia - Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.
  • Increasing excretion of ammonia - Addition of phenylbutyrate, which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product. This can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: All of the following types of interactions cooperate in stabilizing the tertiary structures of globular proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Peptide bonds are not involved in stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins. It forms the primary structure of proteins.

Interactions stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins are as follows:

  • Hydrophobic interactions
  • Hydrogen bonds
  • Ionic interactions
  • Disulphide bonds

Note:

Hydrogen bonds and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the formation of α helix (secondary structure).

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with a history of fatigue, dark-coloured urine and photosensitivity. He consumes alcohol regularly. On examination, hyperpigmentation and scarring are present on the face and dorsum of the hand. Lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 7.4 mg/dl
Peripheral blood picture: Suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anaemia
Urinary porphobilinogen level: Normal
Urinary uroporphyrin level: Increased
questions.solution:
A middle-aged adult presenting with features of hemolysis and photosensitivity with elevated urine uroporphyrin suggests a diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria. It is caused by the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.  It is characterized by photosensivity, which manifests as blistering skin lesions on the back of the hands with crusting and scarring. It is associated with hemochromatosis and patients may develop chronic liver disease. There is increased excretion of uroporphyrin in the urine.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)

(FECH)

Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme does not participate in a ping-pong reaction?
questions.solution:
Aldolase does not participate in a ping-pong reaction. Ping pong reactions are a type of Bi-Bi reaction.

Bi-Bi reaction is a two substrate two product reaction. Most of the Bi-Bi reactions follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics. There are three types of Bi-Bi reactions:

  • Ordered Bi-Bi reaction: Example- NAD(P)H-dependant oxidoreductases.
  • Random Bi-Bi reaction: Example- Most kinases and dehydrogenases.
  • Ping pong reaction: Example- Serine proteases, aminotransferases and pyruvate carboxylase.

questions.text: In the given reaction, two molecules of A combines to form P.  What is the kinetic order of the reaction?

choices.text: 1st order for the forward reaction & 2nd order for the reverse reaction
1st order for the forward reaction & 1st order for the reverse reaction
2nd order for the forward reaction & 1st order for the reverse reaction
2nd order for the forward reaction & 2nd order for the reverse reaction

questions.solution:
The above reaction has 2nd order for the forward reaction and 1st order for the reverse reaction.

The sum of the molar ratios of the reactants defines the kinetic order of the reaction. 

In the forward reaction, A + A → P, the sum of reactants is 2. Thus, 

                                  Rate ∝ [A] [A] or Rate ∝ [A]2

Therefore, the reaction is said to be second order with respect to reactant A.

In the reverse reaction, P → 2 A, the sum of reactants is 1. Thus, 

                                  Rate ∝ [P]

Therefore, the reaction is said to be first order with respect to reactant P.

Kinetic order of reactions:

  • Zero-order reaction: Rate is independent of the concentration of reactants.
  • First-order reaction: Rate is directly proportional to the concentration of one of the reactants.
  • Second-order reaction: In the simplest kind of 2nd order reaction, the rate is proportional to the square of the concentration of one reactant.

questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphofructokinase (PFK-1) is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis. Citrate inhibits the PFK-1.

Mg2+ serves as the co-factor for the enzyme. This step is the committed step of glycolysis.

In general, end products of a reaction on accumulation can inhibit the forward direction progress of any reaction. Substrates and cofactors of an enzyme/reaction will stimulate a reaction/to activate the enzyme, and hence push the reaction in the forward direction.

Inhibitors of PFK-1: ATP, Citrate

Allosteric activators of PFK-1: AMP, ADP, Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (Most potent activator)

Hormonal regulation: Inducer — Insulin, Repressor— Glucagon

Related Pearl: Rate determining enzymes and their key regulators

questions.text: Von Gierke’s disease is due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose 6 phosphatase.

Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), or von Gierke disease, is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. 

Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from:

  • Inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level during the post-absorptive hours of each day
  • Organ changes due to glycogen accumulation
  • Excessive lactic acid generation
  • Damage to tissue from hyperuricemia
  • In GSD bleeding and infection risk from blood cell effects

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

questions.text: To assess the vitamin B1 nutritional status in a patient, measurement of which of the following can be used?
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status.

Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and requires Mg2+ and thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1) as cofactors. In thiamine deficiency, the RBC transketolase activity is reduced. When thiamine diphosphate is added in-vitro to erythrocyte lysate, activation of apo-transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

Other enzymes requiring thiamine as a cofactor are:
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase
Options A and B: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase are involved in the oxidative phase of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. Both enzymes require NADP+ and contribute to the formation of NADPH and ribose.
 
Option D: The vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

questions.text: All mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except:
questions.solution:
All mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Hunter’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In Hunter’s disease, the enzyme iduronate 2-sulphatase is deficient. It is an X-linked condition, affecting males only.

Clinical features of the condition include:

  • Grouped skin papules
  • Extensive Mongolian spots may be an early marker
  • No corneal clouding
  • Communicating hydrocephalus and spastic paraplegia may be seen due to the thickening of meninges
  • Severe form: extensive and progressive CNS deterioration, followed by death by 10–15 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely to cause congenital lactic acidosis in a patient?
questions.solution:
Inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, can be due to a defect in any one/ more of the components of the PDH enzyme complex. This presents with lactic acidosis.

Causes of lactic acidosis:

  1. Tissue hypoxia
  2. Mitochondrial disorders
  3. Deficiency of:   
    • PDH  Enzyme
    • TCA cycle enzymes
    • Vit B1
  4. Poisoning:
    • Cyanide 
    • Mercury
    • Arsenite

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding lipids?
questions.solution:
Lipids are non-polar organic compounds. Hence, they are soluble in organic solvents such as ethanol (alcohol), but insoluble in water.

Lipids are also soluble in nonpolar solvents such as ether, benzene, and chloroform.

questions.text: Each cycle of β-oxidation produces ___________.
questions.solution:
One cycle of β-oxidation of fatty acids produces 1 FADH2, 1 NADH, and 1 acetyl-CoA.

  • FADH2 is formed in the reaction catalyzed by acyl CoA dehydrogenase.
  • NADH is formed in the reaction catalyzed by β-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase
  • In each cycle of β-oxidation, the terminal two carbons are cleaved as acetyl CoA starting at carboxyl end.

Thus, the overall reaction of each cycle of β-oxidation can be summarized as follows:

(Cn)acyl CoA + FAD + NAD++ H2O + CoA → (Cn-2)acyl CoA + FADH2 + NADH + Acetyl CoA +H+

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is NADPH. The most important source of NADPH is the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.

The HMP shunt pathway, or pentose phosphate pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It generates NADPH and synthesizes ribose. NADP+ is hydrogenated to NADPH by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Since the HMP shunt pathway and de novo fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. Thus, this forms the major source for NADPH for fatty acid synthesis. 

Other minor sources of NADPH are extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase and NADP malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme). 

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

questions.text: Which cyclooxygenase enzyme increases during inflammation?
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase enzyme increases during inflammation is COX-2.

Cyclooxygenase (COX), officially known as prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase (PTGS), is an enzyme that is responsible for formation of prostanoids, including thromboxane and prostaglandins such as prostacyclin.

Cyclooxygenase is known to exist in two isoforms COX-1 and COX-2.

While both isoforms catalyse the same reactions but are different in action.

COX-3 Also exist but not in found in human.

Related Pearl: Difference in COX-1 and COX-2

COX-1 COX-2
Synthesize PGs that have housekeeping function (Gastroprotective, haemostasis, renoprotective) Synthesize PGs that mediates Inflammation, pain & fever
Range of expression is 2-4 folds Range of expression is 10-80 folds
Constitutive enzyme Inducible enzyme
Present in most of the cells (Platelets, endothelium, kidney, stomach) Inflammatory sites (Synoviocytes, Fibroblast, Monocytes)

questions.text:
Which of the following lipoproteins have the highest cholesterol:triglyceride ratio?

VLDL- Very low-density lipoprotein

LDL- Low-density lipoprotein 

HDL- High-density lipoprotein 

IDL- Intermediate-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
As cholesterol is the predominant lipid in LDL and HDL, they have a higher cholesterol: triglyceride ratio.

VLDL also has a significant amount of cholesterol but it predominantly comprises triglycerides (lower cholesterol: triglyceride ratio). Therefore LDL and HDL are considered the major carriers of cholesterol.

IDLs are formed by the removal of triglycerides from VLDL by muscle and adipose tissue and are hence enriched in cholesterol. LDLs are derived from VLDL and IDL particles and contain more cholesterol than IDLs.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Burning pain and numbness in hands, heat intolerance, decreased visual acuity with skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder.

Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues. Young boys present with Fabry crises (burning pain in the hands, feet and proximal extremities), angiokeratomas (reddish blue telangiectatic skin lesions between the umbilicus and knees), corneal and lenticular opacities, renal failure and cardiomyopathy.

Note: All sphingolipidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Fabry’s disease.

Most of the common metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive disorders, except:

1. Autosomal dominant disorders:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

2. X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Hunter syndrome
  • Fabry disease
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  • OTC deficiency

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: Which nucleoside triphosphate analogs serve as research tools?
questions.solution:
• Synthetic, non-hydrolyzable analogs of nucleoside triphosphates serve as research tools.
  • They allow investigators to distinguish the effects of nucleotides due to phosphoryl transfer from effects mediated by occupancy of allosteric nucleotide-binding sites on regulated enzymes.

questions.text: What is the rate-limiting step of de novo purine synthesis?

choices.text: PRPP to  Phosphoribosyl amine by PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase
PRPP to Phosphoribosyl amine by PRPP synthetase
Ribose 5-phosphate to PRPP by  PRPP synthetase
Ribose 5-phosphate to PRPP by PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase

questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step of de novo purine synthesis is the conversion of 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP) to phosphoribosylamine by PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase.

The first intermediate formed in the de novo pathway for purine biosynthesis is 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate (PRPP). The rate-limiting enzyme is PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase. This is the committed step in purine nucleotide biosynthesis.

Note: PRPP Glutamyl amidotransferase is activated by PRPP and glutamine and inhibited by AMP and GMP.

Related Pearl: Enzymes of Purine Synthesis Pathway and Their Regulators

Regulators

PRPP Glutamyl Amidotransferase

Inhibited by Amp & GMP

Activator  PRPP

Activated by Glutamine

Diazanorleucine(inhibitor)

Activator pi

Inhibitors  purine ribonucleotides

Formyltransferase

Methotrexate, Anti-folate drugs

VI Synthetase

Azaserine

Adenylosuccinase ,IMP Dehydrogenase

6-mercaptopurine

IMP Dehydrogenase

mycophenolic acid

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA replication?

choices.text: Replication can occur only from a single stranded DNA template
Replication can occur only from a double stranded DNA template
Deoxynucleotide polymerization is catalyzed by helicases
Only DNA polymerase functions at the replication fork

questions.solution:
In all cells, replication can occur only from a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) template.

Steps of DNA replication:

  • Identification of the origins of replication
  • ATP hydrolysis-driven unwinding of dsDNA to provide an ssDNA template
  • Formation of the replication fork; synthesis of RNA primer
  • Initiation of DNA synthesis and elongation
  • Formation of replication bubbles with ligation of the newly synthesized DNA segments
  • Reconstitution of chromatin structure

The replication fork is formed when DNA helicase unwinds a short segment of the parent dsDNA. Primase initiates the synthesis of an RNA primer. DNA polymerase then initiates DNA synthesis (deoxynucleotide polymerisation) in the 3' to 5' direction. Hence, helicase, primase and polymerases act at the replication fork.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

questions.text: During a field trip, an 11-year-old boy consumes a wild mushroom which was later identified to be a death cap mushroom.  Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by the toxin from this mushroom?
questions.solution:
The mushroom death cap (also known as Amanita phalloides) produces the toxin, α-amanitin which inhibits RNA polymerase.

In eukaryotes, α-Amanitin forms a tight complex with the polymerase, thereby inhibiting mRNA synthesis and, ultimately, protein synthesis.

Note: Rifampicin inhibits the prokaryotic DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

questions.text: The lactose operon is likely to be transcribed when ______

choices.text: There is more glucose in the cell than lactose
There is glucose but no lactose in the cell
Cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell

questions.solution:
The lac operon is induced only when cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell.

When lactose is present in abundance, a small amount of lactose is converted to allolactose. This compound binds to the repressor protein of the lac operon and creates a conformational change. As a result, the repressor cannot bind to the operator and transcription of the structural genes occurs. This is an example of negative regulation.

This can only occur when glucose is absent. In the absence of glucose, adenylyl cyclase is active. This generates sufficient quantities of cAMP which bind to catabolite activator protein (CAP).The cAMP–CAP trans-acting complex binds to the CAP-binding site, another regulatory region present upstream of the structural genes of the operon. This causes RNA polymerase to more efficiently initiate transcription at the promoter site. This is an example of positive regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following tools of recombinant DNA technology is incorrectly paired with its use?

choices.text: DNA polymerase - copies DNA sequences in the polymerase chain reaction
DNA ligase - enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends
Reverse transcriptase - production of cDNA from mRNA

questions.solution:
DNA ligase is not paired correctly with its use for cutting DNA and creating sticky ends. DNA ligase joins the adjacent nucleotides in a covalent linkage.

Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific sites creating sticky ends.

Related Pearl: Some Enzymes Used in Recombinant DNA Research

Enzymes

Use

Phosphatases

Removal of 5′-PO4 groups prior to kinase labeling; also used to prevent self-ligation

DNA ligase

Joining of DNA molecules

DNA polymerase I

Synthesis of double-stranded cDNA; nick translation; generation of blunt ends from sticky ends

Thermostable DNA polymerases

Polymerase chain reaction (DNA synthesis)

DNAse I

Nick translation; mapping of hypersensitive sites; mapping protein-DNA interactions

Exonuclease III

DNA sequencing; ChIP-exo, mapping of DNA-protein interactions

λ Exonuclease

DNA sequencing

Polynucleotide kinase

32P end-labeling of DNA or RNA

Reverse transcriptase

Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA; RNA (5′ end) mapping studies

RNAse H

Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA

S1 nuclease

Removal of “hairpin” in synthesis of cDNA; RNA mapping studies (both 5′ and 3′ ends)

Terminal transferase

Homopolymer tailing

Recombinases (CRE, INT, FLP)

Generation of specific chimeric DNA molecules, work both in vitro and in vivo

questions.text: Which of the following represents the recommended dietary allowance of a vitamin or mineral?
questions.solution:
Recommended dietary allowance (RDA) is calculated by using the formula, RDA = EAR + 2SD.  

Estimated average requirement (EAR): The EAR is the average daily nutrient intake level estimated to meet the requirement of one-half of healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

Recommended dietary allowance (RDA): The RDA is the average daily dietary intake level that is sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all individuals in a life stage and gender group. The RDA is calculated based on EAR and is set above the EAR to provide a margin of safety for most individuals. So, RDA is set 2SDs above the EAR.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, a gritty sensation in the eyes, and dry eyes. Examination shows soft corneas. Which of the following is deficient in his retina?
questions.solution:
This patient with difficult dark vision and gritty sensations in the eye with findings of soft corneas suggests vitamin A deficiency. In the retina, a form of vitamin A called retinal (11-cis retinaldehyde) plays an important role in Wald's visual cycle. Its deficiency leads to vision defects.

Rhodopsin, the visual pigment of the rod cells in the retina, consists of 11-cis retinal specifically bound to the protein opsin. When rhodopsin is exposed to light, a series of photochemical isomerizations occurs. This results in the bleaching of the visual pigment and release of all-trans-retinal and opsin. This process triggers a nerve impulse that is transmitted by the optic nerve to the brain.

The image given below shows Wald's visual cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is not required in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine is not required in the TCA cycle.

Vitamins, in the form of their respective coenzymes, are required for the proper functioning of the TCA cycle.

The following vitamins are needed in the TCA cycle:

  • Thiamine as TPP, for decarboxylation in the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction
  • Riboflavin as FAD and FMN, for succinate dehydrogenase
  • Niacin as NAD and NADH, for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase
  • Pantothenic acid as a part of Coenzyme A helps to form acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA

questions.text: A young lady presented with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. On examination, she had fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth. On investigation, she had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tingling sensation of legs and hands, fissured tongue and lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth combined with low RBC glutathione reductase activity is consistent with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

Deficiency state of riboflavin, a water soluble vitamin, is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  1. Cheilosis: Pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin
  2. Glossitis: Tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla causing magenta-colored tongue
  3. Eyes: Keratitis, conjunctivitis and corneal vascularisation
  4. Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia

The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase, by FAD added in vitro. This test is specific for riboflavin deficiency.

The image below shows cheilosis and stomatitis due to riboflavin deficiency.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

questions.text: All the following reactions are involved in generation of reactive oxygen species within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria except ______
questions.solution:
Glutathione peroxidase catalyzes the destruction of hydrogen peroxide.

  • Fenton’s reaction generates hydroxyl radical from H2O2
  • Superoxide dismutase generates H2O2 from superoxide
  • NADPH oxidase reaction generates superoxide from oxygen

questions.text: A forensic team performed a ninhydrin test on some samples obtained from a crime scene. This test can detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ninhydrin test is used to detect amino acids.

A purple-colored complex (Ruhemann's purple) indicates a positive reaction. Proline and hydroxyproline form a yellow adduct with ninhydrin. Glutamine and asparagine produce a brown color.

This test is used effectively used at crime scenes to develop and identify latent fingerprints.

Related Pearl: Reactions or Tests to Identify Specific Groups or Amino Acids

Reactions

Specific Group or Amino Acid

Guanidine group (Arginine)

Nitroprusside Reaction

Sulfhydryl groups (Cysteine)

Sulfur Test

Sulfhydryl groups (Cysteine)

Pauly’s Test

Imidazole ring (Histidine)

Folin-Ciocalteu’s Test

Phenolic group (Tyrosine)

questions.text: Which of the following is the first catecholamine to be synthesized?
questions.solution:
The first catecholamine to be synthesized is dopamine from DOPA.

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

questions.text: During the routine follow-up of a 9-month-old child, you notice a peculiar boiled cabbage odor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Boiled cabbage odor in urine, sweat, and breath occurs in hypermethioninemia. Dimethylsulphide, a metabolite of methionine, causes the characteristic boiled cabbage smell.

People with a genetic deficiency of α/β-methionine adenosyltransferase present with hypermethioninemia and neural demyelination. However, they're usually asymptomatic until early adulthood.

Methionine adenosyltransferase converts methionine to S-adenosyl Methionine (SAM) - a principal methyl donor. Hence the enzyme deficincy causes excess accumulation of methionine and its broken down to metabolites.

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

Tyrosinemia

questions.text: For fatty acid oxidation which of the following intermediate is formed during the transport of acyl-CoA using a mitochondrial shuttle?
questions.solution:
In the fatty acid oxidation process, acyl-carnitine is formed as an intermediate during the transport of acyl-CoA using a mitochondrial shuttle.

Acyl CoA is converted to acyl-carnitine, which is the active form of fatty acid during transport from the cytoplasm to the inside of the mitochondria for oxidation. The enzyme CPT-1 (carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I), present on the outer mitochondrial membrane catalyzes the reaction.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the role of insulin on lipid metabolism?

choices.text: Increasing the transport of glucose into the cells

questions.solution:
Inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase is not an action of insulin. Insulin activates the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme.

Insulin stimulates lipogenesis by the following mechanisms:

  • Decreasing the level of intracellular cAMP. This favours dephosphorylation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase, resulting in its activation. 
  • Increasing acetyl-CoA carboxylase activity. This accelerates the rate-limiting step of fatty acid synthesis.
  • Increasing the transport of glucose into the cell and activation of pyruvate dehydrogenase in the adipose tissue. This yields more acetyl CoA for fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for Farber’s disease?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of ceramide is seen in Farber’s disease.

Farber's disease occurs due to deficiency of ceramidase, which catalyses the breakdown of ceramide to fatty acid and sphingosine. Affected children present with painful joint swelling and nodules, progressive joint deformity, hoarse cry and breathing difficulty, mental retardation and failure to thrive. 

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

3

questions.text: Which is the first intermediate in the conversion of cholesterol to bile acids?
questions.solution:
The first intermediate in the synthesis of bile acids is 7α-hydroxycholesterol

This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme 7α-hydroxylase, a microsomal CYP450 enzyme, which requires NADPH, oxygen, and vitamin C as co-factors. It is the rate-limiting step in the synthesis of bile acids.

Regulation of bile acid synthesis occurs by feedback inhibition of 7α-hydroxylase via the Farnesoid X receptor. When the level of bile acids in the enterohepatic circulation increases, FXR is activated and transcription of the enzyme is suppressed.

Other options:

Option A: 7-dehydrocholesterol is an intermediate in the conversion of cholesterol to vitamin D.

Option C: Lanosterol is an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol.

Option D: Ergosterol is a sterol found in plants.

questions.text: The calorific value of alcohol is _____
questions.solution:
The calorific value of alcohol is 7 Kcal/g.

The caloric value of different food components are:

  • Carbohydrate - 4KCal/g
  • Proteins - 4.2KCal/g
  • Fat - 9Kcal/g
  • Alcohol- 7KCal/g

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest feature in vitamin A deficiency?

choices.text: Loss of sensitivity to green light

questions.solution:
Loss of sensitivity to green light is the earliest feature of vitamin A deficiency while nyctalopia (night blindness) is the earliest symptom of vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can occur as carotenoids (most common - beta carotene from plant sources) or retinoids (from animal sources). Dietary sources of vitamin A are liver, fish, eggs, dark green, and deeply coloured fruits and vegetables.

3 forms of retinoids are:

  • Retinal is required mainly for normal vision (present in the visual pigment rhodopsin).
  • Retinol is important for the normal functioning of the reproductive system.
  • Retinoic acid has a role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.

The sequence of visual defects in vitamin A deficiency:

  1. Loss of sensitivity to green light
  2. Impairment of the eye to adapt to dim light
  3. Night blindness
  4. Bitot spots on the conjunctiva - white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera
  5. Prolonged deficiency of vitamin A → xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  6. If xerophthalmia is not treated, it results in keratomalacia (softening of the cornea), corneal ulceration, corneal scarring and ultimately complete blindness.

The image below shows a Bitot's spot which is pathognomic of vitamin A deficiency.

Other manifestations of vitamin A deficiency:

  • General impairment of immunity
  • Keratinization of skin (phrynoderma/toad skin)

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Related Pearl: Ophthalmic manifestation in vitamin deficiency

Vitamin deficiency Ophthalmic manifestation
A
  • Xerophthalmia
B1
  • Corneal anesthesia
  • Conjunctival and corneal dystrophy
  • Acute retrobulbar neuritis
B2
  • Photophobia
  • Burning sensation
  • Vascularization of the cornea
B12
  • Bilateral centrocecal scotoma
C
  • Hemorrhage in eye
D
  • Zonular cataract
  • Papilledema

questions.text: Strict vegetarians are at a risk of developing a nutritional deficiency of _____
questions.solution:
Strict vegetarians are at risk of developing a nutritional deficiency of vitamin B12.

There are no plant sources as such for vitamin B12/cobalamine.

  • Vitamin B12/cobalamine is synthesized exclusively by microorganisms.
  • Vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin.
  • As a result, strict vegetarians are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of chronic alcohol comsuption presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?

choices.text: Thiamine injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
Diplopia, ataxia and confusion in a patient with chronic alcohol consumption  is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by global confusion, truncal ataxia, ophthalmoplegia and horizontal nystagmus.
  2. Korsakoff psychosis: Symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include memory loss and confabulation
  3. Beriberi: It can be either -
    • Dry beriberi: Sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, muscle weakness
    • Wet beriberi: Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: Which of the following is a chain-breaking antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Antioxidants are used to control and reduce lipid peroxidation during which reactive oxygen species (ROS) are formed. Antioxidants thus fall into two classes:

  • Preventive: These reduce the rate of chain initiation of lipid peroxidation.
  • Chain-breaking: These interfere with the chain propagation phase of lipid peroxidation.

Related Pearl: Types of Antioxidants

Preventive Antioxidants

Chain-breaking Antioxidants
  • Catalase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Chelator of metal Ions-Ceruloplasmin & Transferrin
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Urate
  • Vitamin E
  • Polyphenols

questions.text: A 3-day-old child developed lethargy, poor feeding, and hypotonia. An inborn error of metabolism (IEM) panel was sent. Reports reveal hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia, and homocitrullinuria. What is the most likely defect?
questions.solution:
This child with lethargy, poor feeding, and labs showing hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia, and homocitrullinuria most likely has hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia and homocitrullinuria syndrome (HHH syndrome). This condition is due to an ornithine transporter defect.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: What is the co-factor needed for the isocitrate dehydrogenase enzyme for decarboxylation?
questions.solution:
Isocitrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the decarboxylation of isocitrate, to form α-ketoglutarate. This decarboxylation reaction, requires Mg2+ or Mn2+ ions.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major transporter of ammonia from muscles to liver?
questions.solution:
Alanine is the major transporter of ammonia from muscles to liver. This is by a process called the Cahill cycle.

Alanine is extracted by the liver and undergoes transamination with alpha-ketoglutarate by alanine transaminase (ALT) to form pyruvate and glutamate. Pyruvate is in turn, converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis and glucose is released into the blood.

Glutamate undergoes oxidative deamination and release ammonia which further enters urea cycle.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate), a coenzyme required by kynureninase enzyme to convert 3-OH kynurenine to 3-OH anthranilic acid during tryptophan metabolism.

Related Pearl: Xanthurenic aciduria

questions.text: Which of the following is false about HMP shunt pathway?
questions.solution:
The non-oxidative phase of the HMP pathway is reversible.

In the HMP shunt, no ATP is formed, but the formation of NADPH and ribose takes place. The pentose phosphate pathway is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose.

It does not lead to the formation of ATP, but it has two major functions:

  • Main source of NADPH: important for reductive biosynthesis of fatty acids and steroids, and maintaining reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate 

There are 2 phases in the HMP pathway:

  • Oxidative: irreversible
  • Non-oxidative: reversible

Related Pearl: Phases of HMP Shunt and the Enzymes Involved

Phases

Enzymes

Irreversible oxidative phase

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase

Reversible non-oxidative phase

 

3-Epimerase or Keto-isomerase

Transketolase

Transaldolase

Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: Which of the following is false about glycolysis?

choices.text: 2 ATPs are utilized in the pathway

questions.solution:
The complete breakdown of glucose involves the Krebs cycle (TCA cycle), which occurs in the mitochondria, and not glycolysis.

Glycolysis takes place in the cytoplasm of all cells. 6 carbon-containing glucose is converted to 3 carbon-containing pyruvate in aerobic and lactate in an anaerobic environment. RBC lacks mitochondria and hence completely relies on glucose for energy needs.

Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis and is involved in the conversion of fructose-6-PO4 to fructose 1,6 bisphosphate. This is the slowest reaction in glycolysis and is, therefore, the rate-limiting step. Hexokinase, PFK-1, and pyruvate kinase are involved in 3 irreversible steps of glycolysis.

Net ATP from aerobic glycolysis is 7 ATP. Net ATP from anaerobic glycolysis is 2 ATP. 2 ATP molecules are utilized in glycolysis. Steps releasing ATP in glycolysis are as follows:

  • 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate
  • Phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate

Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes:

• Iodoacetate inhibits glyceraldehyde 3 PO4 dehydrogenase
• Fluoride inhibits enolase
• Arsenate inhibits 1, 3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase step. Arsenic causes glycolysis to produce zero net ATP.
